Discusses: being sent as emissary to Europe, 1946; involvement in Haganah, as of 1934; involvement in Communist Party in Czech Republic; Aliya, 1933 to Givat Haim; preparation for Aliya in 'Tchelet Lavan' movement; rift in Hashomer Hatzair; obtaining gun from British and instructions he received. Born Czech Republic 1914. Aliya to Givat Haim, 1933, as part of movement 'Tchelet Lavan'. Discusses: being sworn into Haganah; role in kibbutz; being drafted into British police; work of 'Tchelet Lavan' in getting members to make Aliya and settle in Kibbutz Givat Haim and later in Kibbutz Ein Gev; Haganah activity and strength; need to improve Haganah activity with outbreak of Arab riots, 1936; being sent by Haganah to join British police.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Roni Schwarz was born in Salzburg in 1958. His family returned to Israel in 1962 and in 1969 they moved to England. In 1976 RS went to Israel to do his military service. Afterwards he studied in England and finally returned to Israel in 1985. Since he had a car accident during his reserve service he is paralyzed. At the time of the interview he was working as lawyer and estate agent in Tel Aviv. He is married and has 2 children.#RS uses a wheelchair, his legs became paralyzed by a car accident during the Lebanon war. His wife is from Egypt but her ancestors have Austrian roots. His grandparents were very successful businessmen in Austria owning several department stores. The grandmother later became a Zionist, emigrated to Israel with her 3 children, and opened a well known vegetarian sanatorium in Zichron Yaakov in 1933. The family owned a big estate there. RS' grandfather did not come with her and was later imprisoned by the Nazis. The family was told that he committed suicide, but maybe this isn't true. RS' mother, who was born in Breslau and survived the Nazi era partly with false documents in Berlin and later in Switzerland, met his father in Israel after the War. During the period the family lived in Salzburg RS' mother deeply detested the Austrians and the German language. His father on the contrary felt quite comfortable in Salzburg even though he had experienced the Austrian anti-Semitism before the war.#RS' grandmother Dora sent his father in the 1920s/30s to a boarding school in Bavaria for some years. He did not feel anti-Semitism, but was mocked at as an Austrian. RS tells an anecdote from an encounter of his father and Hitler, who asked him, whether he, a blond boy with lederhosen, was a member of the Hitlerjugend - his father answered, that he is an Austrian and the Hitlerjugend is forbidden there. After the war RS' father got back some of the families property, that's why he went there to Salzburg with his first wife in 1947. RS' mother was his third wife, RS has 2 full siblings and several half siblings. When RS was 4 years old, the family returned to Israel, because his father had to take over his mother's sanatorium. RS learned Hebrew quickly when they came to Israel. After the sanatorium went bankrupt the family moved to London, and soon English became the language of the family.#RS does not appreciate nationalism, he likes England, Germany and Austria. Sometimes he uses Austrian words. When he visited Austria during the 1970s he started to speak German again. RS thinks that the Austrians are quite tolerant towards strangers today. RS' parents imparted Zionist ideas to him. He doesn't feel emotionally involved in the Holocaust, he considers it as a terrible psychological phenomenon. In his opinion even his father had some “fascist” attitudes. RS tells about a visit to Dachau in the 1970s and about the stories he heard there. He thinks that the Israeli policies towards the Palestinians are in certain aspects comparable to the fascist policies. On the other hand, military operations seem to be the only way to keep the Arabs at bay. He explains some details about the Second Intifada. His attitude towards the political situation worldwide is rather pessimistic. RS is an agnostic and thinks that religious fanaticism is dangerous. He thinks many Israelis might emigrate during a severe conflict, because many own two passports. It is not important to him that the state of Israel keeps its Jewish, religious identity.

It was situated in the south-western part of the old city near to the Authorities' center and was known as the unique 'typical' Jewish quarter of Libya. The photograph shows an old and narrow paved street surmounted by arcades. The street is flanked by several little stalls on both sides and served apparently as a commercial street in the daytime. In the distance appear several men, traditionally dressed. records.title: Members of the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities.

descriptions.value: Born in Transylvania to religious bourgeois Hungarian family. Description of father, Dr. Paul Blau. Studies in Rumania and later in Austria. Arabic studies at Vienna University and Jewish studies at Rabbinical Seminary, 1937. Life during Anschluss and Immigration to Israel. Studies at Hebrew University (HU) until 1942. Teacher in Moriya, religious school in Tel Aviv. Marriage and doctoral studies. Research of medieval Hebrew-Arabic Grammar, modern Arabic dialects and linguistics of Middle Ages. Member of Hagana during War of Independence. Political attitude. Teacher of Hebrew linguistics at Tel Aviv University and in Arabic Department of HU. Academic career. Publications and awards. Member of Hebrew Language Academy.

records.title: The Jewish Underground Movement in the USSR in the 1930s and 1940s.

descriptions.value: Zvi grew up in a small village. His father was a Chassid, his mother's family engaged in agriculture. He got a religious as well as a nationalistic education. During 1920/1 he was a member of Young Agudat Yisrael and studied in a yeshiva. He left the movement after the Dehan affair and established a branch of the Zionist Organization in a small town. He entered a secondary (non-religious) school in Lvov. After he participated in a demonstration in 1927, he was expelled from school and moved to a Jewish school in Lublin and finished in another school there. He started studying at the university of Levow and joined the academic Gordonia. He then moved to Galicia after having joined a political party, and established a branch of the party there. 100,000 Jews lived then in Galizia most of whom worked in agriculture. They could not get entry certificates to Palestine. In 1934/5 the name of the party was changed to Poalei Zion. With the help of Zeev Hering they organized 64 training centres for the Jews of the villages, and it was them who got the first certificates. 80 families went to Palestine in 1935. Zvi Liberman of Nahalal was sent by Histadrut Ha'ovdim to help in this action.#Zvi was head of the Levow branch, in 1938 he was elected member of the executive committee (Va'ad Hapo'el) and in 1939 delegate to the Zionist Congress. He also worked for JNF and Keren Hayesod, organized a group of young Jews to go to Palestine to Kibbutz Ichudiya.#There were several educational institutions in Lvov which taught in Polish. Zvi started work as teacher of Yiddish, and planned with the young people in the seminar to do something against the Russian occupation or to flee. In 1940 Zvi was arrested for allegedly having created a Zionist underground against the Soviet Union. He was transferred several times to various prisons and ended up in Ukraine, put on trial before two Jewish and one Ukrainian judges and sentenced to ten years concentration camp in Siberia. Meanwhile war had broken out. In 1942 Zvi was transferred by train to a concentration camp in Ural where he met other Jewish prisoners, among them Revisionist Assirei Zion. Most Jewish prisoners wanted the Germans to invade, and they made a great mistake by not fleeing into Russia. Because of insufficient and bad food, diarrhea spread in the camp and 90% died of the pest. At some point Zvi was attached to a labour unit, where he almost drowned when trying to get water from a frozen river. The memory of his brother in Israel kept him from taking his life. But he was very weak and sick for a whole year until 1948.#In 1948 the guard of the camp told Zvi about the establishment of the State of Israel and invited him to listen at night to Israel radio. Zvi would then tell his comrades the news. In charge of the camp was a cruel Jew who, having heard about this, called for Zvi one night and interrogated him as to from where Israel had an army, whether there was any agriculture, whether the murder of Colonel Marcus would have any influence on the war, etc. He gave them a lesson in Zionism and was warned not to listen to Radio Israel any more. Zvi continued listening, was arrested and sent to a concentration camp in Potma. After two years, in 1958, he was freed, expelled for life. He went to Siberia, worked as a baker. In 1955 he received a first letter from his brother in Israel, after he had written to him. He went to the NKVD in Krasnoyarsk to ask for permission to leave and go to Israel. This was denied because of the war. Neither did he get permission to be repatriated to Poland. He then flew to Moscow, submitted his request to the General Prosecutor, arguing that he had been arrested because of having been a member of Po'alei Zion in Poland, which was legal. He was "rehabilitated', but his request was not granted. (Here comes a story which is not correct chronologically. He tells of going to Moscow and living with Belikow, an Assir Zion, turned to the Public Notary for help.#There were other Assirei Zion - Zuckerman, Lerer.) In Moscow, from 1966 to 1968, he worked as legal advisor for Betar, taught Hebrew, made friends with the Jews living there and spread the idea of Zionism. He again petitioned the Polish Embassy, got a negative reply. He married, and in 1962 a daughter was born. All his attempts to get permission to leave for Israel, during many years, were denied. A committee was set up to decide who would get permits to go to Israel. Zvi addressed that committee, told them his private story, and this time received the desired permit. He was given 20 days to prepare, and on 5.4.1971 left Russia.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born 1923 to family with Italian citizenship. Outbreak of war in final years of school. Discusses: arrival of refugees to his hometown; Italian government's worsening treatment of Jews; burning of synagogue and community center, 1942; growth of partisans; flight of partisans to mountains upon German conquest, 1943; partisans' inexperience in weaponry; own injury and treatment in Italy; return to Yugoslavia, 1944, serving as military journalist; family's return to Yugoslavia; pursuit of retreating Germans; learning of murder of Jews from his hometown; Aliyah, 1949, with others from same city. (Includes list of people from his hometown who died fighting with partisans).

records.title: One Hundred Years of Jewish Settlement in Argentina; the Argentinian Aliya and Its Absorption in Israel.

descriptions.value: Born in Bessarabia, 1903. After Russian revolution emigrating with some members of his family to Israel, 1919. The remainder emigrating to Argentina. Unification with family in Entre Rios, Argentina, 1927. Life in the agricultural Jewish colony. Return to Tel-Aviv. Return to Argentina due to family problem. Final aliyah to Israel, 1949. Pioneer in moshav Mazkeret Batya. Life as agriculturalist. Presently living in Ashdod.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Amir Tanay grew up in Tel Aviv. He studied medicine in Basel. As a medical doctor he became the head of the Allergy, Immunology and Rheumatology Unit in Wolfson Hospital, Tel Aviv. He is married and has 2 children.#AT's father did not tell him much about the past, neither about his time in Germany, nor about his first years in the country. His father came from Hamburg, but his family originally was from Galicia. He immigrated alone in 1936, he entered the country on a tourist visa and had to go underground for a while. His father's brother had immigrated to Israel earlier and arranged their parents' immigration in 1938. AT's mother also immigrated in 1936 from a small place near Lodz, Poland, with her entire family. His mother told him a lot about her past, two of her siblings were killed in concentration camps. But she described her youth in Poland very romantically and in details. Her father had owned a taylor's workshop with several employees. Before emigrating to Palestine he came to buy some land. However when the family arrived it turned out he was cheated or a mistake was made, and the family lived rather miserably. His paternal grandmother died before he was born, his paternal grandfather lived with them until he was eight years old. AT shared a room with his brother and his grandfather. His parents were both working. After school, instead of playing with other children, AT always had to accompany his grandfather, who used to chat with some friends. He did not have any common language with his grandfather, they communicated in a very “skeletal”, broken Hebrew.#The grandfather looked very strange to him, always dressed in black, with a kipa and a little beard, always very serious. The maternal grandparents were very different, they had a Polish behavior, talked very loudly and laughed a lot. Around the age of puberty, AT rebelled against the Polish mentality and preferred the Yekkish way of life for a while . He appreciated coffee and cake in the afternoon, their style to celebrate family festivities etc., and was convinced this type of mentality was more adequate to him than the East European one. However today AT has a tendency towards his Polish roots. During AT's study in Basel his father visited him, and they developed a much closer relationship than before. AT explains that in Israel there was a tension between the first and second generation: the parents wanted their children to grow up without the burden of their parents' past and the diaspora, while their children wanted to grow up as sabres, keeping distance to anything which was typical for the diaspora. AT thinks that the history of the Yekkes even complicated the normal generation conflict. When he was 7 or 8 years old, he joined the youth movement and went twice a week to the meetings. Their ideal was to become a pioneer in a kibbutz, to go to Nahal etc. While studying in Basel his friends pointed out that AT was always talking about " we Israelis" instead of " I". It's an example of how the collective was very important for his generation. AT thinks that his father (like probably many Yekkes) slowly acculturated to the Levant and was no longer a typical Yekke in his later years.#AT did not speak German as a child, his brother did. Their parents spoke German and English with each other, and sometimes they spoke some Yiddish. During his study, he began to learn German. He was good enough after one year and later spoke German fluently and without an accent. AT's children were in Germany with him. He and his children have many friends in Germany.#AT explains the political situation from a historical perspective. He thinks Israel is still more oriented towards the US than to Europe, but that Europe has a considerable cultural influence.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Born 12/28/1905, Katowice. Education: high school, trade school, study of medicine, 1934/34 carpenter training (Hachshara). Emigration: 1933 flight to Paris, Bologna, 1934 return to Kattowitz, 1935 Palestine. Career: carpenter in Haifa, Jerusalem, accident in 1936 from then office work, "Ford Company" in Jerusalem, 42 years branch manager, retirement with 68; scientific bibliographer at University-clinic. Finished his medicine studies in the meantime. Interview: Biographical data about his childhood and youth. Parents owned a hotel in Kattowitz. 5 semesters in Halle, then Cologne. About his siblings. Anti-Semitic experiences in Cologne, left over night and fled to Paris. Found work, went to Bologna with two friends. Stayed with a rich Jewish family and nursed an old family member. One of the daughters wanted to marry him, but he already knew he was going to marry his wife. Married 01/01/1935. They emigrated on the day of the wedding. Found work immediately in Palestine, good salary. Wife was a hat maker and had enough work. Partnership with a boutique owner. Accident: he broke his spine and had to quit his job. One year in a wheel chair then job with "Ford Motor Company". Further career, 40 years with Ford. After retirement work for Triumph. Sickness and surgeries. Interest in Medicine woke again and he volunteered to work for a Professor. Organized a library for the hospital. Graduated in Medicine at the age of 75. About the meaning of work for his life, age, hobbies,#Rotary-Club. Interest for the East. Sen-Buddhism and travels to Japan. 2 sons. Knows Japanese. Knows Hebrew well. With their children they spoke German. Arabic friends. No religious education. Identifies with the idea of Zionism. Doesn't know enough about Judaism. Considers himself an absolute atheist. Religious lessons in school. 3 Jews in his class. Many friends in school. Adjusting to Israel. His parents had a Zionist touch. Thinks that he would have achieved more in Germany. His mother and his wife's family died in Auschwitz. How he got the certificate for his mother but couldn't get one for his mother in law. Brother immigrated illegally. Sister lived in St. Gallen and had to go to the USA. His sister's family. Why he did not join a Kibbutz. About his work. About a project about hospitals in Jerusalem in the 19th Century and a dissertation by a German doctor.

The beginning of "illegal" immigration from Romania. Financing revisionist "illegal" immigration. The sailing of the boat "Rim". Relations with the Romanian authorities. Conversation with Eichmann. Escape from Romania and immigration to Palestine.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Served as captain in U.S. Army, Mannheim, Germany. Discusses: Us Army's entrance into Mannheim; encountering and working with Rabbi Hazelkorn; devoted activity of Harold Weiss; effectiveness of chaplains; working with Hazelkorn to establish Langenzall camp for Jewish survivors; Dwight Eisenhower's visit to their camp; contact with Jewish Brigade; working to reunite families.

records.title: The Jewish Community in Tunisia and its Zionist Activity.

descriptions.value: Betar in the 1930s. Relations with non-Jews. Establishment of school for Betar commanders. Betar activities under the Vichy regime and the German occupation. Biography of her husband Ephraim Luzon and his brothe Elie. Immigration to Israel.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Krym Peninsula, USSR, 1922. Medical studies at institute for pediatric medicine in Leningrad. Continuing studies in Krym due to outbreak of war, graduating in 1946. Moving to Vilna in search of employment. Marriage. Forging documents and hiding profession in order to relocate to Lodz as repatriates. Staying at Betar pioneer training center (hakhsahra). Relocation to Hessisch Lichtenau in the American occupation zone in Germany. Practicing medicine there for first time. Employed by UNRAA and American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee. Received formal certificate as physician from Joint after interview in Munich. Relocation to Bergen Belsen after eighteen months; obtaining there a certificate to immigrate to Israel. Sailing from Marseilles to Israel on immigrant ship in May, 1948. Received abandoned house in Haifa. Short term work in Rothschild Hospital in Haifa. Pediatrician in Shaar Haaliya from its establishment. Director of small children's clinic and isolation rooms in camp. Classifying newcomers' medical condition.
Production period - beginning of the 20th century#Category - Synagogues

records.title: USSR Born Jewish Soldiers who Served in the Red Army in World War II.

descriptions.value: The witness was born in the Vinitzer region of Ukraine. Enlisted in the army, aged 24, together with other students. Talks about Professor Falkowich and the soldiers' willingness to serve on the front; some of the Jews who fell while serving in the Red Army are enscribed in a war memorial in Moscow. He also talks about his integration in the army, structure of the divisions, number of Jews in his platoon; soldier relationships; German propaganda; essence of his Judaism 1937-1938; how his Jewishness influenced his relationship with his comrades in arms; motivation of the Jewish soldiers to fight against the Germans; sources of information on the Germans' intentions regarding the Jews; relations with the Russian soldiers; his intent to avenge the Germans; list of names of professors killed; surmises that Jews were deliberately sent to the front; topics of conversation between the soldiers; Jews known to him in the free Soviet areas; how Jews became officers and generals; his experience in the Red Army; how he identified the Jews in the army.

Relations between academicians and SC judges. Hazards of over system. Independence of the SC in the coming years. Religious legislation in Italy, Germany and the USA. Born Graz, Austria in 1910. Attended elementary school in Chomutou, Sudetes and moved to Praga after invasion. Worked for HicemHIAS, since 1938 ties with Joint. Helped people to leave the country working from Praga, Milan, North Africa and Switzerland. Ties with Bundesgemande in Locarno, and Intelectuele Comitte in Geneva. Immigrated as technician to Sousua, Dominican Republic, with intervention of AgroJoint. Itinerary: Switzerland, France, Spain, Portugal, Ellis Island (USA), Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic. Founded a chemical industry for the government. Lived in Mexico since 1947. Active in Hatikva Menorah, Spinoza Lodge. Participated in the Committee pro Jews in the URSS.

Grandson of famous scholar Prof. M.D. Cassuto and son of one-time chief rabbi of Florence. Parents arrested and sent to Auschwitz, World War II. Catholic families in Florence host him and his brother until liberation of city. Aliyah to Israel with brothers, 1945. Architect and advisor to minister of religion on matters of architecture. Member of the Israeli Committee for the Memory of the Unknown Soldier. Chief of Hevrat Yehudei Italia (Italian Jewish Society). Member of "Dante Alighieri Italian Cultural Society", Jerusalem.

Discusses: reaction of Uruguay government to nationalization of Suez Canal and Sinai War; own diplomatic activity fighting UN sanctions against Israel; economic reasons behind Uruguay's opposition to nationalization of Suez Canal and establishment of State; position on this issue in third world countries and amidst both left and right-wing; Uruguay's position of 'Fedayeen' and Arab refugees; influence Arab sanctions had on opinion in Uruguay; presentation of Israel's diplomatic position as way of obtaining UN support; survey of events following Israeli withdrawal, 1957; Israeli PR in Uruguay and Latin America; role in peace efforts (1961; '63; '64) presented in UN by Latin American and African countries; conversation with Pinchas Sapir on trade agreements; support of Israeli 'Red Party'; Fabregat's support in Israel; Jews as political force in Uruguay.
Childhood in Baden. Antisemitic experiences at school. Move to Vienna and then to Palestine. Fighting in Gush Etzion, prisoner of war, teaching in Jerusalem.

records.title: The life stories of child survivors living in Israel.

descriptions.value: Born Poland, 1932. Studied in illicit Jewish school, 1940-42. Discusses: liquidation of Ghetto, transfer of Jews to Auschwitz; being sent to labour camp where made socks; dismantling of camp with approach of Russians, 1944; being sent to Auschwitz; reasons for not being killed; fate of family; surviving death march and Mengele's selection; German attempt at evacuating camps and hiding evidence of murders as Russians approached; further deaths as inmates were marched out of camps; liberation, 1945; residing in hostel for refugee children; pride in encountering Jewish Brigade; going to Israel via Italy; learning of mother's survival; absorption into Israeli society; serving as soldier (age 16) in War of Independence; studying social sciences in University; his research on the Holocaust; visiting Auschwitz, 1988.

records.title: Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Resident of Kefar Sava. Enlisted into Lehi with Hanoch Kalay. Supported treaties based on common interests, eg. with Poland which wanted to be rid of its Jews. Some left Lehi because of such treaties, others because they lacked idealistic or mental strength. Cohen considered Yair an idealogue, leader, passionate revolutionary. Difficult period followed Yair's murder: persecution by the Hagana; persecution by the British; failed missions; terrible finances; desertion and dispersion of many members. 1943: Lehi reunited, reorganize and cleansed ranks of traitors. 1944: killing of informants; attempted clash with High Commissioner; Cohen imprisoned; declaration of Begin-Etzel revolt.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Zagreb, 1917; member of Hashomer-Hatzair. Served in Yugoslavian army. Made Aliyah, 1939. Joined Palmah. Discusses: recruiting Yugoslavian-born Israelis to fight Nazis, 1942; failed parachuting attempts; finding family members among Yugoslavian refugees in Italy; organizing European Jews to fight, and helping them avoid the camps; involvement in Yugoslavian partisans as part of British army; parachuting supplies; organization of Zagreb Jewish community following German retreat; helping surviving members of youth movement go to Israel; learning of Hannah Senesh's mission and transfer to Hungary; returning to Israel and reporting to Teddy Kollek.

אגרת מאת ר' משה אבן מכיר מצפת אל קהילות תורכיה שהתחייבו לתמוך ב"הסגר" (ישיבה) שהקים בצפת ר' משה שלח את חתנו ר' שלמה מור דוד לאסוף תרומות, אך הלה נחשד שהוא אוסף תרומות בטענות שווא. בדף הנוכחי נדפסה אגרתו של ר' משה בן מכיר, עדות על נאמנות חתימתו (מאת ר' יצחק גרשון ואברהם ויזינו) ואישור של בית-דין בויניציאה: ר' יהודה סרוואל ר' עזרא ב"ר יצחק מפאנו ור' משה נפתלי הכהן התמרי, יט בשולי העמוד: "כל זה נעשה להשתדלות המשתדל במנה הזאת ... ר' שלמה מור דוד ... לבלום פי המנגדים ... ואולי בראותם הכתב הלז ... יסגרו פיהם. וכל המחזיק במצוה הזאת שכרו כפול ...". דף זה בשלמותו חזר ונדפס על ידי ד' תמר, מחקרים בתולדות היהודים בארץ ישראל ובארצות המזרח, ירושלים תשמ"א, עמ' 194-196. ועיין גם: א' יערי, שלוחי ארץ ישראל, עמ' 844-845; מ' בניהו, איגרת רבי משה ן' מכיר לקהלות תורכיה בעד ההסגר בעין זיתון, אסופות, טו, תשס"ג, עמ' רתט-שד.#A declaration from the rabbinical court of Venice attesting to the legitimacy of the fundraising efforts of Rabbi Solomon b. Nahmias Mor David, son-in-law of Rabbi Moses ibn Makhir, on behalf of the latter's yeshivah in Safed. When accusations against Mor David, questioning the authority for his mission, began to circulate, the Venetian rabbinical court issued this document, which includes a copy of a letter from ibn Makhir, as well as testimony about the authenticity of his signature. Dated Friday, the thirty-fifth day of the Omer (21 Iyyar) 5360 (May 5, 1600). With decorative elements. Reprinted in Tamar, Mehkarim be-Toledot ha-Yehudim, 194 - 196. See also Yaari, Sheluhei Eretz Yisra'el, 844 - 845; Benayahu, “Iggeret Rabbi Mosheh ibn Makhir,” 298 - 309.

Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Orit Zaslavsky's parents lived in kibbutz Hulata until she was two years old, then they moved to Jerusalem. Her parents divorced when she was eight years old. OZ then lived with her mother in New York for one year, afterwards she lived with her father in Israel. After having finished high school she served two years in the military. She studied Mathematics in Jerusalem and moved to Haifa in 1972. She got married and continued her studies, of which two years in the US. She got a doctorate from the Technion in Haifa in 1987. Later she also did a post-doctorate at the university of Pittsburgh. She is a professor of Mathematics Education at the Technion Haifa.#OZ's father and her uncle Ari came to Israel without their parents with the Youth Aliyah. Her grandfather at that time was in Dachau, when he was released he emigrated to the US. Her father had a hard time getting used to the kibbutz. OZ's parents got to know each other when her father went to see her grandfather in the US after the war. Her parents left the kibbutz when she was 2 years old and they divorced when she was 8. After a year with her mother in New York she moved to her father in Jerusalem. When OZ was 10 years old, both of her parents had married again and she stayed mainly with her father. She grew up in Rehavia, the most Yekkish quarter of Jerusalem. Her father, who became a lawyer, was very dominant in her life. OZ always had a close relationship to her father's brother Ari Rath. Rath worked as a journalist and later editor of the “Jerusalem Post”, OZ often visited him after school.#OZ describes the difference between the two brothers: they did not always get along well, though they usually were proud of each other. Her uncle expected a lot from her, she sometimes felt pressurized by him. Political knowledge was very important to him. Nowadays he still often stays with her for the holidays. He took her children to Vienna to show them their roots. OZ decided to learn Latin because of her father's and her uncle's influence, who had to leave their grammar school with ancient languages before they could finish it. OZ former husband, the father of her 3 children, was an engineer. She now has a new partner, from Bukovina. OZ first wanted to study law, but then decided not to follow in her father's footsteps. Her father wants his grandchildren to achieve academic degrees, but OZ does not consider this an absolutely necessity. Her eldest son gave up his studies and is now producing movies. One of OZ's children criticized her that she does not motivate them to study. Her daughter and her first son had a good relationship to OZ's mother. Her children have a rather difficult relationship with their grandfather. Her second son has a good relationship with her uncle Ari.#OZ's parents spoke English with each other and sometimes Yiddish, but never German. OZ spoke English with her mother. She did not want to learn German, there was a time she could not stand the language. When she finally came to Germany and Austria her opinion changed. OZ has got many Yekkish acquaintances. She describes the difference between her mother and her father. Her maternal grandparents came from Eastern Europe, OZ and her parents went to see them several times. One aunt, his father's half-sister, grew up in America and behaved more American. Later this aunt immigrated to Israel. OZ's father and her uncle are not typical Yekkes either in OZ's opinion: they are untidy, unpunctual and very lively.#OZ came to Vienna for the first time with her father and her uncle. She had been to Austria before, but didn't want to go to Vienna. Her father and her uncle don't have negative feelings towards the city. Her father goes to Germany often, he worked for the embassy in Bonn. OZ describes her attitude towards Austrians and Germans; she thinks she can trust her uncle's friends in Europe.#OZ thinks that there are big differences between the generations and their culture. Some Israeli traditions are still popular among all generations. OZ describes problems with her Arab students in Haifa, who sometimes do not accept their training methods. Also there are demonstrations on campus often and there is always some fear in her mind.

descriptions.value: The 5th visit of PM Menahem Begin in Egypt to discuss the Peace Process between Egypt and Israel. Photo shows: On way to visit the Assuan Hidroelectric Station.
The 5th visit of PM Menahem Begin in Egypt to discuss the Peace Process between Egypt and Israel. Photo shows: On way to visit the Assuan Hidroelectric Station.

Prime Minister Itzhak Rabin and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak had a three and a half hour summit meeting in Ismailiya today. Arriving aboard an Israel Air Force airliner, Rabin was met at Ismailiya Airport by the Egyptian prime minister, Atif Sadki. Following a guard of honour Rabin was taken by an Egyptian Air Force helicopter to a near by villa for his meeting with Mubarak. The meeting between the two leaders was very cordial and in a press conference following the meeting Mubarak said that the Palestinians must attend the talks next week in the U.S. The President made no criticisa of Israel's refusal to make further concessions to the Palestinians before the reconvening of the Peace confewrence. This is the second time that Rabin has met with Mubarak on Egyptian soil since Rabin came to power last year. There is such concern in Israel that Wubarak still refuses to make an official visit to Israel. The true extent of peace between Israel and Egyptian is still very much a one way affair.; Photo shows: Israeli press-photographers takes snapshot with the Egyptian soldiers for history.

records.title: Two new Nahal settlements were established near Sakhnin near this Galilee Arab village.

descriptions.value: One of them, Atzmon, is populated by members of Garin Moran and is affiliated with Ihud Hakvutzot Vehakibutzim. The other is Eshhar and belongs to the Kibbutz Hameuhad movement. The soldiers-farmers are living in tents, but construction has begun on permament housing. A Defence Ministry source said no land had been expropriated for the new settlements as both are on state-owned land. During the last three years, five Nahal settlements have been established in Galilee and two more will be added in coming weeks. Photo shows: The official ceremony of oening the new Nahal settlement Atzmon.

Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek has threatened to cancel the forthcoming 25th anniversary celebration of Jerusalem's reunification following the 1967 Six Day War. The mayor, always an outspoken critic of government poIicy, has threatened the cancellation of the celebration because of the situation created by Jewish settlement in the East Jerusalem village of Silwan. Kollek was concerned about the image abroad as well as the extra burden that has been put on the security forces to maintain law and order. Today thousands of Jewish left-wing peace activists joined with Arab villagers in Silwan to protest the Jewish settlers effort to take over their homes. The protest went off without incident even though there was a very small right-wing counter protest. Photo shows protestors beginning to arrive in Silwan for a demonstration in support of Jewish settlers not living in Arab villages in East Jerusalem 20/12//91 Copyright © IPPA.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון בהילולת הבבא סאלי בתאריך 30 בינואר 2020, ד' בשבט התש"פ , בנתיבות. בבא (אבא) סאלי (ישראל) אבו חצירא (1889-1984) היה רב במרוקו ובישראל שהיה מקובל כעושה ניסים ומביא ברכה. לאחר פטירתו ירש אותו בנו, בבא ברוך. ביום פטירת הבבא סאלי, ד' בשבט, נערכת מאז 1985 הילולה סביב קברו בנתיבות. ההילולה משכה בתחילה בעיקר יוצאי מרוקו שבאו ביום הפטירה. במשך השנים גדלה והתרחבה ההילולה וכיום היא נמשכת יומיים ובאים אליה למעלה מרבע מיליון מאמינים מרוב שדרות הציבור. הילולת הבבא סאלי היא הגדולה שבהילולות שעל קברי צדיקים. במשך השנים נבנו מבנים גדולים על הקבר וכיום, בניגוד לבעבר, קיימת הפרדה מוקפדת בין גברים ונשים. הקרן הקיימת נטעה פארק, בצורת חמסה, מסביב לקבר שבימי ההילולה מתקיים בו שוק גדול. בתצלומים ניתן לראות את התפילה שנערכת באוהל הגדול שהוקם על יד המצבה, ארוחות שמתקיימות במהלך ימי ההילולה, תצלומים מהשוק שמתקיים בפארק קק"ל ואת פולחן זריקת הנרות.תפילה אל מול המצבה: רוב הבאים מתחילים בתפילה ב"אוהל" הגדול שהוקם על המצבה.קוסקוס ומופלטות: רבים מביאים אוכל ומקיימים סעודות עליזות. נשים רבות מחלקות אוכל וממתקים לקהל וגברים מגישים משקאות חריפים.שוק של מצוות: באזור הקבר מוכרים אנשי הבבא ברוך נרות, מאחיה (עראק) קדוש, שמן מקודש, ספרים ושאר דברים המביאים ברכה(בעבר היו מוכרים גם בקבוקים עם מים קדושים). ביום ההילולה הראשון, ערב יום הפטירה, מתקיימת תהלוכה המוליכה ספר תורה מביתו של הבבא אל הקבר. אנשים משלמים עבור הזכות לשאת את ספר התורה. השוק הגדול: הפארק של קק"ל הופך בימי ההילולה לשוק ענק, שמוכרים בו כל מיני חפצים הנושאים את דמות הבבא סאלי, תכשיטים, כיסויי ראש לנשים וכיפות לגברים, כלי בית ושאר חפצים ודוכני מזון.פולחן זריקת הנרות: פולחן הנרות הוא פולחן חדש שהתפתח עם השנים. בשנת 1987 בעת שהיתו של דנצ'ו בהילולה, אנשים ונשים הדליקו נרות על בתוך האוהל שנבנה על המצבה. עם השנים, רבו הנרות ואי אפשר היה לשהות באוהל בגלל העשן לשם כך, התקינו מיתקן שריפה ממתכת מחוץ לאוהל, ליד היציאה, ואנשים הדליקו את הנרות בתוכו. כשרבו המדליקים, היה מסוכן להתקרב למיתקן מחמת האש החזקה ולכן גידרו אותו והמדליקים נאלצו להשליך את הנרות הדולקים מרחוק פנימה. כך החל פולחן הנרות; מדליקים נר, מבקשים בקשה וזורקים פנימה. אם מצליחים לקלוע, הבקשה תתקבל. בשנים האחרונות יש מיתקנים נפרדים לנשים ולגברים, אך מיתקן הנשים פופולארי יותר ורק גברים מעטים זורקים במיתקן שלהם.

descriptions.value: הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שבו נראה ביתו הפרטי של חיים נחמן ביאליק ברחוב ביאליק, תל אביב, בעת בנייתו. תצלום זה נעשה בעת העבודות להשלמת הקומה הראשונה של הבית, בחודש נובמבר 1924. בראש הבית, מימין לשמאל, נראים: המפקח על הבנייה מטעם הפועלים, משה ברמן; המשורר חיים נחמן ביאליק; המפקח על הבנייה מטעם ביאליק, שמואל (סם) ברקאי. קיצוני משמאל, נראה אריה וינברג, אחד מן הפועלים שהשתתף בבנייה. על התצלום כתב ויינברג בדיו: "בשנת תרפ"ה בונים אנו בית למר ח. נ. ביאליק ברחוב ח. נ. ביאליק, תל אביב, ארצנו הקדושה". בצדו השמאלי של התצלום, מעל לבתים הנראים באופק, ציין וינברג כי זוהי "שכונת נורדיה". תצלום זה נתרם לספרייה הלאומית בשנת 1935 על ידי מר אריה ויינברג, נחלת יהודה.

records.title: Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Galicia, 1918. Fleeing to Russia on outbreak of WWII, where she worked in accounting. Return to Poland, 1946. Relocation from Bytom to Lodz. Accountant in coordination offices of childrens' houses (handling the funds used to rescue Jewish children). Observing difficulties of children survivors of which many refused to reassume Jewish identity after many years of Christian upbringing. Praising rescuers who spent a lot of effort, persuasion and money to take Jewish children out of Christian families and convents. After staying a while in childrens' houses children were sent illegaly to Israel with help of emissaries from different political parties. In July 1949 Polish authorities began controlling transference of children and closed the office. Interviewee managing to hide important documents that the Central Jewish Committee wanted to hide from the Polish authorities.

records.title: Jewish Underground Movement in the USSR in the 1930s and 1940s.

descriptions.value: Activities of Zionist Bnai Zion and Zeirei Zion in late 1920s and early 1930 in Vinnitsa area. Several activists arrested in that period and sent to Siberia. Meeting in Siberia of groups from various areas in Soviet Union.

David was born in Sighet Marmaţiei, Romania. His family were Vizhnitz Hassidim. They spoke Yiddish. David went to cheder and then to public and secondary school. He had 2 younger sisters who survived Auschwitz. David joined a Zionist youth movement, without telling his parents. He was in the partisans and spent time as a prisoner of war in Russia. After the war, he married Devorah and was sent to settle in the Sudetenland with other Jews. After many unsuccessful applications to emigrate, he and his family were given permission to immigrate to Israel. They lived in Tiberias. He served in the Israeli Police Force. Devorah talks a little about her Holocaust experiences. After the Holocaust, the Czechs treated the Jewish survivors well.

records.title: Testimonies from Holocaust Survivors in the United States.

descriptions.value: Discusses: Alliance between Czechoslovakia and Germany; Anti-Jewish Codex in Slovakia; Establishment of Jewish resistance; deportations and murder of locals; missions done for resistance (helping people escape; obtaining food; fighting Germans); people risking selves to help others; members of his group; capture and escape; treatment by non-Jews in Lipa; make-up, missions and interaction in Lipa.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sofia, Bulgaria in 1923. Family neither Zionist nor assimilationist. Member of Betar youth movement. Family deported during WWII with all Jews of Sofiya. Arrival in Ruse. Return to Sofiya after war. Continuing studies. Sister immigrating to Israel, 1948. Family waiting for his graduation from technical school and not joining mass immigration to Israel of Bulgarian Jews. Aliya in 1950, among last Bulgarian families. Entrusting their property in Bulgaria to relatives who stayed behind. Welcomed by Israeli relatives. Various experiences in Shaar Haaliya. Living in a shack with another thirty people at Bat Galim immigrant house Later receiving private room and after one year moving to rented apartment. Finding employment as engineer at Barbur ceramic tiles factory in Akko. Father remained unemployed.

records.title: Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Warsaw, 1934. Only child of well off Polish speaking family. Parents having social and commercial contacts with Poles. After father had been taken away and conditions in the ghetto worsened, mother deciding to relocate to Aryan side with help (for a fee) of Polish acquaintances. Being separated from his mother. Suffering a lot due to separation. Relocated from one family to another for three years until 1944. In 1944 contact was established with mother's brother, an officer in Polish Army and a bachelor who could not keep him and thus relocated him to a convent. Due to pressure converting to Christianity and becoming the priest's assistant. Difficult living conditions: scarce food supply and harsh discipline. Taken out of the convent by wife of a cousin but due to their difficult economic condition transfered to Jewish childrens' house in Bielsko, one of communist orientation. Relatives who were Zionists later relocating him to Zionist childrens' house in Gliwice. Suffering much provocation by the other children due to Christian belief which took him a long time to forget. Aliya in 1948. Settling in moshav Talmei Yafe. Never forgiving his family for not taking him in.

records.title: Jews in the Czechoslovak Armies in World War II.

descriptions.value: Deported to Nisko, Poland. From there to USSR. Sent to work camps. Moved to Urals. Joined Svoboda unit in Buzuluk, 1942. Battle of Sokolovo. Antisemitism in unit, despite Jews serving in high positions. Became active in political policing. Joined Hagana after war. Aliya, 1949. List of Czech Jews who died in battle.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Novisad, 1922, to middle-class Zionist family. Studied History. Member of youth movement. Editor of newspaper. Involved in pre-military training in youth camps. With outbreak of war was asked to establish Jewish Brigade for Hungarian army. Discusses: anti-Semitism among Hungarians; conflict between Jewish Hungarian youths and Nazis, leading to unification of all Jewish youth movements; Yugoslavian hatred of Germans after joining Nazi block Yugoslavian attempt at neutrality; joint German and Hungarian attack on Belgrade; destruction of Yugoslavian army; entrance of Hungarian army into Novisad, and subsequent murder of 600 residents, mostly Serbs; preference of Hungarian over German rule; Hungarians organizing Jews into work camps, and fining Jewish community; improved situation due to help from Hungarian Jews; beginning of Partisan activity, 1941, at initiation of Communists; involvement in intelligence; murder of entire family in Aktzion, except father who received warning and fled to Hungary; own flight to Hungary with Partisans; capture and life sentence, served from 1942-1944; majority of Partisans imprisoned were Jewish; cooperation between head of prison and prisoners allowing continued underground work; 1944 draft into Hungarian army and continuing involvement with Partisans; organization of escape of all members of Hungarian Partisans; Gestapo murder of entire unit of Hungarian officers involved in underground; German attempt at enlisting Yugoslavian prisoners#to send to front; managing to escape forced draft by purchasing Croatian passport; working for Partisan prisoners; establishing contact with Jewish Russian officers; fighting with Yugoslavian army near Austria.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Former mayor of Beer Sheva. Memories from 1947-1948, then engineer for Solel Boneh on the Southern Command in Israel, heading 300 workers. Only several secluded settlements in the Negev then with no water or defense. Organization of contact between Southern settlements and the army who took care of food supplies and protection. Camp settled in Nir-Am, until the front moved south and then settled in deserted houses in Beer-Sheva in 21.10.1948. This being the outset of the civilian foundation of the city. In 1949 when Golda Meir was Minister of Labor, resources were found for raw materials for building the city in the nearby dunes of Revivim. Connecting to water supplies from local wells and to electricity and telephone lines with minimum expenses and a lot of good will on part of the state authorities. 7,000 people in immigrant camp during snowy winter of 1950. Beginning of education in city conducted in schools from British mandate period. The Histadrut investing a fortune in Beer-Sheva out of a will to assist absorption of newcomers. Commending the establishment of the university in city which helps promote matters of culture and education. Claims that the government should take it to distribute the population and settle half of the forth million that will arrive to Israel between 1973-1983 in the Negev, with Beer Sheva as the central city in this district.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: UNED Aliya from Iraq, 1951, with husband and children. Member of youth movement in Iraq and dreamed of Degania. Resided in Shaar Aliya then in Beer Yaakov Maabara. Felt life in the Maabara was good, despite hardships. Began to feel discrimination between the eastern and European immigrants. Extended family arrived and sent to Tirat Hakarmel Maabara. Tova moved to Tirat Hakarmel. Joined Kibbutz Degania Bet.

Jews in the Underground in Belgium during World War II; The Rescue of Jewish Children in Belgium during World War II; The Rescue of Children from Germany, Czechoslovakia and Austria via Western Europe, 1933-1940.

descriptions.value: Born in Warsaw, active in Zionist youth movement "Mercaz". Arrived in Belgium in 1920. Active in "General Zionists" and organizing a Hachsharah for Belgium youth at Villers-la-Ville; With German occupation in 1940 fled to France, but returned to Belgium in June 1940, when synagogues in Brussels reopened and regular activities resumed. Public soup kitchen opened in time becoming meeting place for various other activities. In June 1942 Germans demanded Belgian Jews to wear yellow badges. On July 22, 1942 young people ordered to go to Mechlin. Hid with wife at home of Belgium woman; moved to new place every few months. Through prewar clock business ties with Switzerland succeeded in contacting Saly Mayer and then Nijkerk. Obtained money from Switzerland to assist 500 needy families. He and wife alone handled 175 families, procuring false documents, packages, newspapers in Yiddish, money and so on. Postmen helped by passing on to Jewish organizations letters of the informers meant for Gestapo, thus allowing them to prevent many deportations. Via Switzerland, obtained emigration certificates to Eretz Yisrael (July 1944); 99 percent of those who received certificates were saved. Succeeded in maintaining contact with their family in Warsaw via coded letters. Knew already in summer of 1942 about extermination of Polish Jewry. Involved in project of translating the Talmud into Yiddish, 4.5 tractates of which appeared after the war.

records.title: Jewish Resistance in Slovakia during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born in Bratislava, studied at 'Obchodma Akademia', was in Hungary from 1941-43. Left Budapest for Slovakia when Germans arrived, joined the Partisans. Falsified documents. Arrested by Gestapo, towards end of war worked as a welder for the S.S. After war joined 'Hashomer Hatzair', accompanying groups from the 'Bricha' to Haifa on the Theodore Herzl ship. In Palestine involved with several Kibbutzim. Discusses: reasons for joining Partisans and not the regular army; discovery of fascists among Partisans; issue of anti-semitism in fighting units; effort made by Jews to get to liberated territory or to the Partisans; his capture and interrogation by Gestapo; his group's field of action; arms; falsified documents.

records.title: Resistance Movement in the Cracow Ghetto during the Nazi Occupation.

descriptions.value: Born in Cracow, 1925. Activities as member of Hashomer Hatzair underground as a young boy. Bunker built by movement as rescue place at time of ghetto's liquidation aktion, with the intention to flee to the forests after that to continue activities from there. Missions outside the ghetto. His life since liquidation of the ghetto (13.3.1943). Transfered with his brother Moshe to Plaszow. Their survival. Liquidation of Mr. Chilevitz, successor of Simcha Shapira as head of the Ordenung-Dienst, the Jewish Police in Plaszow. Attitude of Jewish and Ukranian officers in the camp towards Jews. Cruelty of Jewish officers who hoped to gain favors for this in due time but were disappointed.

records.title: The Educational Systems in Jewish DPS Camps in Germany and Austria 1945-1951.

descriptions.value: Aliya in 1934, joined Kevutza Massada, then moved to Kevutza Avuka in Bet Shean valley. Worked caring for babies. After World War II, on her own initiative, asked to join Eretz Israel delegation to Europe. Worked in displaced persons camps in American zone in Germany during 1946; After re-evaluation by 22nd Zionist Congress of activities of Eretz Israel delegation moved to Austria. Active there until end of summer 1947, mainly in organizing children's activity in camps around Salzburg.

records.title: The Resistance Movement in the Cracow Ghetto during the Nazi Occupation.

descriptions.value: Both being drafted to Hehalutz Halohem underground by Gusta Draenger, 1942, during stay in Bochnia. Establishment of branch of Hehalutz Halohem. Branch members incarcerated in Montelupich prison. Underground bunker in Bochnia and its capture by the Nazis in March 1943. Hashomer Hadati in Cracow on the eve of WWII. Naftali Rab commander of fighters group of Hashomer Hadati within the framework of Hehalutz Halohem. Second bunker in Bochnia established when first group grew too large. Leader Hillel Wadzislawski last commander after death or arrest of all others. Wadzislawski's preparations for relocation to the forests in the coming spring. Capture of bunker due to betrayal by Jolek Appel and Natek Weisman following the expropriation operation in which they participated. Humiliation and tortures in Montelupich prison.

records.title: ק.ק.ל. עיר גנים דרומית לירושלים [חומר קרטוגרפי].
Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Nurit Lieber-Leffmann grew up in Haifa. During her military service she worked with the air traffic control. She followed a teacher training. In 1966 she moved to Be'er Sheva and in 1974 to Kiryat Tivon. She did a MA in Tel Aviv. NLL worked as a teacher and later became superintendent of Arabic-Israeli schools till she retired after a car accident. She married in 1966, got 3 children, divorced and remarried.#NLL's father was an orthopaedic surgeon; her parents met when her father studied in Heidelberg and they got married in Karlsruhe. Her mother did not have higher education. Her parents came to Israel because of a friend; her father considered himself by that time a communist, not a Zionist. Her paternal grandparents immigrated in 1936 and moved in with NLL's parents. Her grandfather was very educated and taught NLL many things about the German culture.#NLL learned Hebrew only in the kindergarten. Her family lived on Hadar Hakarmel in Haifa, their environment was Yekkish. Her family appreciated the “Prussian” values; her father taught her songs from World War I. Her parents never earned a lot of money, because her father always worked for the Kupat Cholim and treated poor patients without taking money. He was already sick after his retirement and was depressive and took his own life. She admired her father but her sister always had problems with him. Their household was run typically “German” and her grandmother cooked German dishes. On Friday evenings her father used to read German literature to the family. She remembers her children's books still very well, like the Grimm's fairytales. NLL's elder sister wanted to join a kibbutz when she was very young and revolted against their father. Sometimes the sisters were told they should feel ashamed for their Yekkish upbringing. They were educated very strictly, e.g. with respect to table manners. There hardly was physical proximity and warmth in her family, but humor was important.#NLL has conducted some interviews with Yekkes, starting from the 1980s. Her daughter learned about the Yekkes for her school-leaving exams and NLL wanted to know whether other families gave their children the same education which she had. In the beginning NLL only interviewed her parents' friends and did not work very professionally, a friend helped her to make the interviews more systematical with a a questionnaire. NLL's parents were very much involved in her education. Her parents favourized her first marriage because her husband, an engineer and childhood friend, came from a Yekkish family. They married in 1966 and moved to Be'er Sheva, where she for the first time experienced different ethnic groups and their warm, spontaneous behavior. Their daughters were born in 1970 and 1972, and their son in 1979. In 1974 they moved to Kiryat Tivon because of her husband's profession. Later NLL did her MA in Tel Aviv. After being married for 18 years NLL and her first husband got divorced. Her second husband came from Canada in 1962 and had Polish parents; he often teases NLL because of her Yekkish background and behavior.NLL tells about her work as superintendent of Arab-Israeli schools. NLL is worried about the nationalist movements in the educational system and regrets that she has never had Arabic lessons. She retired after a serious car accident.#NLL's parents did not appreciate the Hebrew learning contents of their daughters school education. NLL speaks Hebrew with a slight German accent. Her father did not like the many religious and nationalist elements in the Israeli school education. NLL thinks that the interpersonal Yekkish virtues are very important. She compares the Middle Eastern hospitability to the reserved Yekkish behavior. When she was a child, NLL came to kibbutz Daliya every year and considered the poor living conditions and the pressure to solidarity in the kibbutz as very depressing. Her father treated many Arabs so NLL sometimes had contacts with them.#NLL has never been to Germany but has heard a lot about it, she could imagine to go to Berlin one day with her daughter and her Dutch son-in-law. Her mother was invited by the city of Heidelberg, but she did not go there. NLL had some German friends because of her first husband. NLL describes the situation of the Ethiopian immigrants and racist tendencies in the Israeli society. She talks about exchange programs between Germany and Israel. NLL would have liked to hear more about the past from her parents and would like to meet someone who could read the personal diaries of her father in German Gothic handwriting. She tells about the contacts with their Yekkish neighbors, the Kolaths.
His life as a oud player in Iraq.

records.title: Evacuation and Flight of Jews in the USSR during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born in Tulchin, Ukraine, 1921. Studies in Vinnitsa, Ukraine. Return to parents' home in Tulchin at beginning of WWII, 1941. Family fleeing to Stalingrad through Gaisin, July 1941. Move to Tashkent through Kuybyshev, September 1941.

Born Morocco, 1936. Father died 1946. Discusses: family business; community's appointment of guardian over family when father died; mother continuing father's business once he died; other work she did to sustain family financially; studies; becoming involved in Zionist movement 'Habonim'; influence 'Habonim' had on his life and connection to Israel; hachshara in France; Aliyah, 1951.

records.title: The Zionist Underground in Soviet-Occupied Poland, 1939-1941.

descriptions.value: לפני המלחמה המרואיין (בן 21) שהה בהכשרת ברדום. עם תחילתה הוא וחבריו החלו לנדוד מזרחה, והתרחקו מהחזית הגרמנית. הגיע לביתו ברובנה, שם חווה את כניסתם של הרוסים. החל בתכנונים לחצות את הגבול הרומני. לאחר שהניסיון שכל והרוסים תפסוהו, נשלח למעצר ממושך בבתי הכלא הרוסיים. נושאים עיקריים בראיון: המצב בתחילת המלמחה בערים ובייערות שבהן עברו בדרכו מזרחה, הלכי הרוח ובעיות הקיום בשבועות הראשונים; השפעת הכיבוש הרוסי על פעולות התנועה, בעיות ההסתגלות לשלטונות ומציאת אלטרנטיבה. הנסיון הכושל לחציית הגבול לרומניה. השהייה במעצר בבתי כלא שונים. נשלח מזרחב להמשך מעצר וחקירה. תנאי הקיום במעצר ובדרכים בין מתקני הכליאה, הקשר עם אסירים אחרים (עם חבריו ועם אסירים אותם לא הכיר - גויים ויהודים).

records.title: Emek Zeboulon zone d'habitation plan de lotissement des trois sections.
Hospitium et Ecclesia Succursalis Tripolis (ad mare)

descriptions.value: The church and belltower. The church is surrounded by a brick wall. Three men and a priest are in the photograph.

From old Rabbinic Iraqi family. Married 1910. Arrived Shanghai, 1913. Later grandfather, (a Rabbi, Mohel and Shohet) also came. Had 6 children in China. Lived in Japanese area. Discusses: absence of anti-Semitism; Jewish life - synagogue, religious and cultural events; donations of buildings from wealthy Iraqi families; pro-British sentiments of family; continuation of studies in English school; learning Jewish studies from grandfather; sephardic families that made fortunes during Opium Wars and had British passports and influence in British government - lived separately from other Jews, didn't participate in Zionist activity, but contributed greatly to Jewish charities and religious organizations; exception of Ezra family - that also took part in Zionist activity; division in Iraqi Jewish community between wealthy with British passports, and middle-class; rescue project for Kaipeng Jewish community, attempted synagogue restoration; success of some families in transferring businesses to Hong-Kong and obtaining influential positions in London, with rise of Communism; working as journalist for 'China-Press' from 1938, and during war; learning, from contact with Japanese and Chinese, of German pressure to establish death camps; simple and comfortable lifestyle in Shanghai; potential Shanghai had to develop before Communism arrived, 1946; growth of own interest in Zionism and Etzel; parents' and oldest brother's move to America; own Aliyah with three younger brothers.
The Valley of Hinnom hillside and some of the tombs on it.

records.title: History of the Palestine Communist Party - PKP.

descriptions.value: Immigration to Israel from Poland, 1939. Member of Hashomer Hatzair. Leaving kibbutz Binyamina in protest against exploitation of Arab workers. Joining the Palestine Communist Party (PKP). Heading a list of candidates for the Women Workers Committee. Jewish-Arab relations within the PKP. Ideological problems during WWII.

records.title: Jalil el Qibliya : Jaffa sub-dist. Block plan reduction / Survey of Palestine תוקן והודפס ע"י מחלקת המדידות.
Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen. Immigration from Yemen in 1949 through Hashed Geula camp in Aden. Attended by emissaries of Jewish Agency. Defrauded of jewelry and valuables by fellow Yemenite olim and Ashkenazi emissaries. Messianism among Yemenite Jews while immigrating. Arrival in Rosh Haayin. Newcomers' hair and side-locks forcibly cut. Yemenite Mapai repesentatives objecting to Yemenite olim joining religious parties. Daily life and absorption process in immigrant camp. Disappearance of newborn baby from children's house and unfulfilled promises of his return. Relocation to Elyashiv transitional camp, 1951-1952. Enlisting in the Israel Defense Forces. Relocation to Emek Hefer transitional settlement, 1953-1954. Struggle between Histadrut and religious parties. Activities for promotion of religious education. Losing job due to membership in Hapoel Hamizrahi. Establishment of enquiry committee to investigate disappearance of Yemenite children.

records.title: Absorption of Jews from Arab Countries in Israel.

descriptions.value: Born Northern Iraq, 1923. Discusses: personal biography; making Aliya via Syria, 1938; arriving in Israel; serving in British police; being drafted to IDF, 1948; story behind establishment of Moshav Azaria, 1949; serving as social leader in moshavs of new immigrants; different jobs and appointments held - particularly involving new immigrants; education; wife and children, their education; living conditions; language spoken at home; food; social environment; religion; hobbies.

records.title: בית אריזה של תפוחים בקיבוץ יפעת.
Jews of the Areas Annexed to the USSR in World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Bucharest. Was reserve officer in Romanian army. Called up for service as Soviets approached. Discusses: Tiraspol, Bessrabia; army experience; being only Jewish officer; understanding need to flee as Soviets approached; experience of Jewish soldiers in Romanian army; how Jews responded to Romanian officers; his own experience with other Jews in Kishniev train station; returning to Bucharest; receiving Soviet permission to return to Romania; Romanian refusal to allow Jews to return; two year imprisonment in Romania on suspicion of being Soviet spy; 6 years in Soviet concentration camp; Aliya.
